Different species don't interbreed. Sapiens, Neanderthal, & Denisova are three races of H. sapiens (what are modernly referred to as races are, in fact, ethnicities, as they are entirely cultural). If Longi represents a separate branch, then it should be called another race of human, not another species.

Even then, I suspect it is within the range of variation for H. sapiens sapiens. The history of human evolution is fraught with people deciding to designate a single skull or fragment as a new species—in no small part due to this giving them access to more funding. But look at modern humans. If we acted like these researchers, then comparing the skeletons of modern humans (one standard deviation) smaller than average to human skeletons (one standard deviation) larger than average (i.e., throwing out extreme outliers that would be less likely to remain in a fossil record) would result in calling them two different species.

you do know that modern humans are only considered one species (now) because we defined it that way, and that these other humans are different species because we defined it that way, right? there is no objective truth to these classifications. and notably, prior to the founding of Israel and the Civil Rights Movement in the US, it was pretty common for scientists to consider various modern ethnicities as different human species. this might be troubling to the 'woke' crowd, but it's actually more intellectually honest when you consider what constitutes species-hood in other animals.

for instance, modern gorilla populations fall into several species because they look very slightly different from each other. they can all interbreed, they fill the same ecological niche, yadda yadda, but they're very slightly different colors and sizes, so they're different species. compare this to humans, where you get a comparatively huge range of sizes and skin colors, hair colors and textures, eye colors, facial geometries, even dietary requirements, but we're all one species and we reached that conclusion right about the same time it was pointed out that genocides aren't cool. seems fishy.

We don't know a lot about the physical characteristics of Denisovans, but the little we do know indicates that "Dragon Man" (and the recent find in Israel) share key features with Denisovans, one of the distinguishing features being absolutely massive teeth.

Increasingly it's looking like there may have been significant regional variations in Denisovans, with a possibility that what we are calling Denisovans may actually be a species complex rather than a single species.

There is a lot more research necessary before any definitive clams can be made, and, as is often the case, especially here in Asia, claims of the find being a new species are wildly premature.

Everyone wants their name linked with a new species, and there is also a huge amount of national pride linked to new hominins, especially when it comes to China.

Both of these topics are really interesting but I also just wanted to say I'm really digging the visual update 😊 Especially the blob wipe transitions and switch to sentence case for text. The intro is also excellent. Props to everyone involved!
